results.title: Charlie Chaplin. Vol. 03
results.brief_description: This compilation video features four of Charlie Chaplin’s short films. “Easy street”: Charlie becomes a policeman and imposes his own brand of order on chaotic Easy Street. “The Immigrant”: Charlie meets a beautiful girl on board a ship. After many hilarious hardships they rescue each other and live happily ever after. “The Cure”: Our hero deposits the contents of his liquor bottle into the curative spa at a Sanatorium. “The Adventurer”: The hectic experiences of an escaped convict, with Charlie starring as the convict.

results.title: Charlie Chaplin. Vol. 02
results.brief_description: This compilation features four of Charlie Chaplin’s short films. “The Pawnshop”: Chaplin stars as the pawnbroker’s assistant. “The Rink”: Chaplin as the waiter. “The Floorwalker” and “One A.M.”: Chaplin as the drunk.

results.title: Child of the future: how he might learn
results.creator_credit: Theodore Conant and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Education is increasingly affected by technological advances. Shows how schools and colleges are shedding their traditional apathy to machines and are now exploiting all manner of mechanical and electronic aids and how these changes affect the child. Several leading educators and innovators including Dr. Marshall McLuhan and Dr. Jerome Bruner of Havard University discuss the ways traditional practice is adapting to radical new methods.

results.title: Charlie Chaplin. Vol. 01
results.brief_description: Charlie Chaplin was born on April 6, 1889 in South London, of not so successful music hall entertainers. At the age of eight, he joined a variety act called “The Eight Lancashire Lads”, and worked throughout England and parts of Europe during his childhood. He toured America in 1910-11 and returned again in 1912-13 when he joined the Keystone company. This compilation features four of his short films, The Vagabond”, “The Fireman”, “The Count” and “Behind the Screen.

results.title: Charlie's angels [DVD]
results.creator_credit: McG, Drew Barrymore, Leonard Goldberg, Nancy Juvonen and Global Entertainment
results.brief_description: This big screen adaptation of the popular 70s TV series sees the return of the beautiful, brilliant and sassy angels who work for billionaire recluse, Charles Townsend. Together with their fellow colleague, Bosley, they are sent to work when an electronic genius, Eric Knox, is kidnapped. They soon discover even bigger problems are at bay when they realise Knox’s latest technology is a system which can monitor voice communication from anywhere in the world. This is an exuberant action comedy which never takes itself seriously, combining modern day themes with elements of 70s cheese. Cast includes: Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore, Lucy Liu, Bill Murray, Sam Rockwell, Tim Curry, Kelly Lynch, Crispin Glover and the voice of John Forsythe as Charlie.

constellations_other.name: What's in a name?
constellations_other.description: Pakeezah (1972) star Meena Kumari was not just 'the tragedy queen' of Hindi film – she also wrote poetry under the pseudonym Naaz. From famous families and stage names to gendered disguises, this Constellation explores how women have adopted different names and identities to facilitate their ambition.

results.title: Child molestation: when to say no
results.creator_credit: Dana Young, Elizabeth Young and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: Uses four dramatisations to illustrate typical encounters between a child and a child molester. Shows the child how to thwart the attempt of molestation and stresses the importance of reporting such incidents to a responsible adult. Suitable for middle and upper primary school levels.

results.title: Child guidance clinic [Abridged version]
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, Allen Stark and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Narrator Neil Leroy drops in at the Child Adjustment Services center for the study and treatment of the emotionally disturbed child set up by the Toronto Board of Education. Here, psychologists, social workers and psychiatrists, with the cooperation of parents and teachers, are learning how to deal with children’s emotional problems and to help them develop into healthy, happy adults. Through the story of young Nick, we see how early diagnosis and treatment of a child’s maladjustment can change him into a normal, outgoing youngster.

results.title: Charley Squash goes to town
results.creator_credit: Duke Redbird and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated film, based on an Indian comic-strip character created by Duke Redbird, telling the story of a young Indian who leaves the reserve to make his way in the city. Eventually he returns to the reserve and the ways of his people. Animation: Yvon Mallette, Marie Claire Berube. Voice and narration: Isaac Beaulieu. (Award: Philadelphia)

results.title: Child draw nearer
results.creator_credit: Annie Mygind, Martin Shuttleworth and Bristol Films
results.brief_description: This film shows the advances made at a special school for teaching autistic children and how they began to respond to patience and to use language in a normal way. Commentary by Norman Tyrrell and Val Bryan.

results.title: Child care: the management challenge for the 1990's
results.creator_credit: Mark Gould, Susan Lambert and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty percent of all women workers have children under five and in 56% of families with dependent children, both parents work. Inadequate childcare facilities for these working parents can result in high absenteeism, low productivity and a high turnover rate. More and more companies are seeing the advantages to providing a carefully planned work-based childcare centre which ultimately benefits not just the employees, but the employer and the children. This video provides several examples of Sydney-based companies who have taken the initiative, including the Vacation Program run jointly by the NAB, ANZ, NML and CML, the Messengers Cottage Creche for the Esso/Lend Lease employees and the Flemington Market’s proposed childcare centre. The consensus appears to be a higher retention of skilled workers, particularly women, and an overall improvement in productivity.
